item.title: Roswell (film)
item.description:
Roswell (film) ðŸ”—

This entry details the 1994 American science fiction television film Roswell, also known as Roswell: The U.F.O. Cover-Up. The film is based on the alleged Roswell UFO incident, which involves the U.S. military’s supposed capture of a flying saucer and its alien crew after a crash near Roswell, New Mexico, in July 1947. The film also references other UFOlogy events, including Area 51, alien autopsies, the death of James Forrestal, and Majestic-12.

Plot ðŸ”—

The plot unfolds through flashbacks at a 30-year reunion of the 509th Operations Group. It centers on Major Jesse Marcel’s investigation into strange debris found on a rancher’s field in July 1947. Despite being told by his superiors that it was merely a downed weather balloon, Marcel persists in his search for the truth, ultimately uncovering the reality of what occurred. Key figures include Major Jesse Marcel and the setting is Roswell, New Mexico.

Reception ðŸ”—

The film received reviews from The New York Times, Variety, and The Los Angeles Times. The New York Times praised the film’s tense drama but questioned the plausibility of a long-term cover-up. Variety called it a gripping fictional account and highlighted the convincing pacing and unflinching portrayal of military mendacity. The Los Angeles Times viewed the film as more than just a sci-fi story, focusing on the protagonist’s search for truth.

Cast ðŸ”—

The cast includes Kyle MacLachlan as Jesse A. Marcel, Martin Sheen as Townsend, and Dwight Yoakam as Mac Brazel. Other notable cast members include Xander Berkeley, Bob Gunton, Kim Greist, Peter MacNicol, John M. Jackson, and Nick Searcy. The cast also features appearances by Charles Hallahan, Ray McKinnon, Eugene Roche, and Charles Martin Smith.

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the citations used in the article, including reviews from The New York Times, Variety, and The Los Angeles Times.

item.title: David Grusch UFO whistleblower claims
item.description:
David Grusch: Former U.S. Military Intelligence Officer’s Claims About “Non-Human” Spacecraft Recovery ðŸ”—

This article focuses on the claims made by David Grusch, a former U.S. Air Force officer and intelligence official, regarding the U.S. government’s alleged involvement in recovering and reverse-engineering “non-human” spacecraft. It also covers the responses to these claims from various experts and government entities.

Background ðŸ”—

David Charles Grusch is introduced as an Afghanistan combat veteran and former intelligence officer who worked at the National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency (NGA) and the National Reconnaissance Office (NRO). From 2019 to 2021, he served as the NRO representative to the Unidentified Aerial Phenomena Task Force. He assisted in drafting the National Defense Authorization Act of 2023, which included whistleblower protections for UFO reporting. The section notes that Congressional interest in UFOs increased prior to Grusch’s claims due to the downing of four objects by the Air Force in February 2023.

Grusch’s Claims ðŸ”—

This section details the specific claims made by David Grusch. He alleges that the U.S. federal government maintains a highly secretive UFO retrieval program, possessing multiple spacecraft of “non-human” origin and the deceased pilots. He also claims there is evidence of white-collar crime to conceal these programs and that officials have stated people were killed to maintain secrecy.

Grusch further elaborated on his claims in an interview with Le Parisien, suggesting UFOs could be from extra dimensions and that the U.S. government transferred crashed UFOs to a defense contractor.

During a Congressional hearing in July 2023, Grusch testified that he was informed of a multi-decade UAP crash retrieval and reverse-engineering program, but was denied access. He stated that the U.S. government possesses UAP based on interviews with 40 witnesses. He also claimed the U.S. has retrieved “non-human ‘biologics’” from the crafts. When asked about harm or injury related to cover-ups, Grusch said yes, but could only provide details in a SCIF.

Responses from Relevant Experts ðŸ”—

This section presents the perspectives of various experts on Grusch’s claims. It highlights that his assertions are primarily based on alleged documents and conversations, rather than testable evidence. The scientific community generally views claims of government concealment of extraterrestrial visitation as untrue due to a lack of supporting evidence.

Joshua Semeter of NASA’s UAP independent study team emphasizes the lack of data or material evidence. Adam Frank, an astrophysics professor, criticizes the claims as hearsay. Stuart Clark’s opinion piece in The Guardian includes questions from scientists like Avi Loeb, Michael Garrett, and Sara Russell, who point out the lack of observed extraterrestrial activity and the ease of identifying extraterrestrial materials.

Greg Eghigian, a history professor, notes the historical pattern of individuals making “bombshell allegations” about UFOs without corroboration. Seth Shostak of the SETI Institute questions the lack of physical evidence and dismisses the claims as an “argument from authority.” Michael Shermer of Skeptic magazine notes the absence of physical evidence and scientific community involvement.

Physicist Sean M. Carroll calls the evidence “laughable” and describes Grusch as a “complete crackpot.” NASA’s JPL director Laurie Leshin denies seeing spacecraft from outside Earth. Michio Kaku suggests the burden of proof has shifted to the Pentagon, a statement Ross Pomeroy criticizes as unscientific.

Responses from the United States Government ðŸ”—

This section outlines the responses from various U.S. government entities to Grusch’s claims.

White House Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre referred questions to the Department of Defense (DoD). The Pentagon stated that AARO has not discovered any verifiable information to substantiate claims of programs regarding the possession or reverse-engineering of extraterrestrial materials.

General Mark Milley, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, stated he had never encountered evidence to verify Grusch’s claims. NASA stated it has not found any credible evidence of extraterrestrial life and no evidence that UAPs are extraterrestrial.

Representative Mike Turner, chairman of the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence, stated there is no evidence to support claims of the U.S. possessing UFOs from outer space. Senator Lindsey Graham found the claims unreasonable. Senator Josh Hawley expressed less surprise, while other senators, like Kirsten Gillibrand and Marco Rubio, expressed concern about potential unbriefed special access programs and firsthand knowledge from individuals.

Senators Chuck Schumer and Mike Rounds proposed the UAP Disclosure Act 2023, an amendment to the 2024 National Defence Authorization Act, to increase access to UAP records. The enrolled bill directs the National Archives to collect government documents about UAPs.

Members of the House Oversight Committee’s national security subcommittee received a classified briefing from the Intelligence Community Inspector General (IC IG) Thomas A. Monheim regarding UAP reporting transparency. Some members expressed frustration with the lack of new information.

2023 House Committee Oversight and Accountability Hearing ðŸ”—

Representatives Anna Paulina Luna and Tim Burchett organized a hearing on July 26, 2023, in response to Grusch’s claims. Grusch testified, repeating his earlier UFO claims. Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez asked where to look for evidence, to which Grusch offered to provide specific information in a closed environment. Officials later informed lawmakers that Grusch lacked the security clearance to discuss the issues in a SCIF. A bipartisan group of U.S. representatives called for the formation of a select committee on UAPs with subpoena power.

AARO’s director Sean Kirkpatrick criticized Grusch for refusing to speak with AARO and described the hearing as “insulting” to DoD and Intelligence Community officers.

Sean Kirkpatrick ðŸ”—

After retiring from AARO, Kirkpatrick wrote an opinion piece for Scientific American stating that the US Government UFO coverup allegations “derive from inadvertent or unauthorized disclosures of legitimate U.S. programs or related R&D that have nothing to do with extraterrestrial issues or technology.” He described the allegations’ supporters as “a small group of interconnected believers and others with possibly less than honest intentions,” who promote a “whirlwind of tall tales, fabrication and secondhand or thirdhand retellings”.

In an interview with Peter Bergen, Kirkpatrick said that Grusch may have misinterpreted things or fallen under the influence of a core group of people. He characterized the situation as a conspiracy by UFO true believers to get the government involved in investigating aliens, a “self licking ice cream cone”.

Media Reporting on Grusch’s Claims ðŸ”—

This section examines how the media has covered Grusch’s claims.

Connections to Studies Funded by Robert Bigelow ðŸ”—

Keith Kloor writing for Scientific American draws a connection between Grusch’s claims and studies funded by Robert Bigelow, noting the specific reference to “a football fieldâ€“sized UFO” in both Grusch’s claims and past claims by Bigelow.

Reporting on Psychiatric Treatment Received by Grusch ðŸ”—

Ken Klippenstein reported in The Intercept that Grusch was twice committed after incidents involving drunkenness and suicidal comments. Police records mentioned PTSD. Grusch was placed under an emergency custody order and transported to an emergency room, then transferred to an inpatient psychiatric program. The article noted that Grusch’s ability to keep his security clearance despite this history “appears to contrast with the government’s treatment of other employees”. Grusch later sued Loudoun County Sheriff for releasing the information.

News Stories and Commentary ðŸ”—

Nick Pope, who previously ran the British Ministry of Defense “UFO Desk,” expressed hope for confirmation but notes the difficulty given Grusch’s lost security clearance and lack of a “smoking gun.”

Marina Koren wrote in The Atlantic that the case fits a pattern of unprovable claims. Matt Laslo, writing for Wired, described the sympathetic hearing of Grusch’s claims by some members of Congress as an indication that once-fringe notions have built-in fan bases. Tucker Carlson publicized the claims in a video posted to Twitter and in an interview with Grusch. Tom Rogan, writing in the Washington Examiner, was skeptical but opined that the claims should be investigated.

Andrew Prokop, writing for Vox, noted that skeptics question whether Grusch is repeating tall tales and that mainstream media sources have remained wary. Sean Thomas expressed confusion that others have tried to convince officials and the public that UFOs are worthy of serious consideration. The New York Times columnist Ross Douthat noted that one interpretation is that parts of the U.S. government see benefit in promoting belief in UFOs. Matt Stieb, writing for New York, described Grusch’s claims as “crazy.”

Ezra Klein, a columnist with The New York Times, interviewed Leslie Kean, noting the polarized reactions to the story. Steven Greenstreet, a documentary filmmaker, criticized Grusch for associating with ufologists Jeremy Corbell and George Knapp.

The story received attention from multiple foreign mainstream news outlets.

Grusch claimed that intentional disinformation was being promoted by the US government to cast doubt on the veracity of “non-human” UFO claims. item.title: Roswell incident
item.description:
UFO Legend Caused by 1947 Balloon Crash: Roswell Incident ðŸ”—

The Roswell incident is a cornerstone of UFO lore, stemming from the recovery of debris near Roswell, New Mexico, in 1947. Initially reported as a “flying disc” capture, the U.S. Army quickly retracted the statement, claiming it was a weather balloon. This event, coupled with subsequent government explanations and retractions, fueled decades of conspiracy theories alleging a cover-up of extraterrestrial contact.

1947 Military Balloon Crash ðŸ”—

This section details the initial event and its immediate aftermath. In 1947, rancher W.W. “Mac” Brazel discovered debris on his property near Corona, New Mexico. The debris consisted of tinfoil, rubber, tape, and wooden beams. Unaware of the ongoing “flying disc craze,” Brazel initially didn’t connect the debris to UFOs. However, after visiting Corona, his uncle suggested it could be from a “flying disk.” Brazel reported the findings to Sheriff George Wilcox, who contacted Roswell Army Air Field (RAAF).

RAAF sent Major Jesse Marcel and Captain Sheridan Cavitt to investigate. A press release issued by public information officer Walter Haut announced the military’s recovery of a “flying disc.” This announcement made international headlines but was quickly retracted. General Roger Ramey and weather officer Irving Newton identified the material as a weather balloon at a press conference.

UFO Conspiracy Theories (1947â€“1978) ðŸ”—

This section explores the period between the initial incident and the rise of modern Roswell conspiracy theories. The Roswell debris retrieval faded from public attention for three decades. However, belief in government UFO cover-ups grew, fueled by hoaxes and legends of crashed spaceships and alien bodies in New Mexico. The Aztec, New Mexico crashed saucer hoax introduced the idea of recovered alien bodies, which later became associated with Roswell. The concept of “Hangar 18,” a fictional location at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, emerged as a storage site for alien craft and bodies.

Roswell Conspiracy Theories (1978â€“1994) ðŸ”—

This section details the resurgence of interest in Roswell and the development of modern conspiracy theories. In 1978, ufologist Stanton Friedman interviewed Jesse Marcel, who stated that the “weather balloon” explanation was a cover story and that he believed the debris was extraterrestrial. This interview, along with subsequent media attention, reignited interest in the Roswell incident.

The 1980 book The Roswell Incident by Charles Berlitz and Bill Moore popularized Marcel’s account and added the claim of alien bodies found on the Plains of San Agustin. The book also connected Marcel’s account to Lydia Sleppy, a former teletype operator who claimed she was ordered to stop transmitting a story about crashed saucer wreckage.

The Majestic 12 hoax, involving faked government documents, emerged in the 1980s, further fueling conspiracy theories. Glenn Dennis, a former mortician, provided an account of extraterrestrial corpses, which was endorsed by prominent Roswell ufologists.

Competing accounts of the Roswell incident led to a schism among ufologists in the early 1990s. UFO Crash at Roswell by Kevin Randle and Donald Schmitt added testimony from new witnesses. Crash at Corona by Stanton Friedman and Don Berliner introduced the idea of two crashed saucers and eight aliens. The Truth About the UFO Crash at Roswell by Randle and Schmitt proposed a new crash site and a different group of archaeologists.

Air Force Response ðŸ”—

This section outlines the official government response to the growing Roswell conspiracy theories. Under pressure from New Mexico congressman Steven Schiff and the General Accounting Office (GAO), the Air Force published reports in the mid-1990s. The initial 1994 report admitted that the weather balloon explanation was a cover story for Project Mogul, a military surveillance program. The 1995 report, The Roswell Report: Fact vs. Fiction in the New Mexico Desert, supported this with documentation that narrowed the cause of the debris to a specific Mogul balloon train. The 1997 report, The Roswell Report: Case Closed, detailed how eyewitness accounts of military personnel loading aliens into “body bags” matched the Air Force’s procedures for retrieving parachute test dummies.

Later Theories and Hoaxes (1994â€“Present) ðŸ”—

This section covers the continued development of Roswell theories and hoaxes in recent decades. Alien Autopsy: Fact or Fiction, a pseudo-documentary, played a major role in shaping popular opinion of Roswell. The film centered around Ray Santilli’s hoaxed footage of an alien autopsy.

In 1997, retired army intelligence officer Philip J. Corso released The Day After Roswell, alleging that he was shown a nonhuman body and helped oversee a project to reverse engineer recovered crash debris.

Other theories include Annie Jacobsen’s Area 51: An Uncensored History of America’s Top Secret Military Base, which featured a claim that Nazi doctor Josef Mengele was recruited by Soviet leader Joseph Stalin to produce “grotesque, child-size aviators.”

Explanations ðŸ”—

This section presents the explanations for the Roswell incident, focusing on Project Mogul and anthropomorphic dummies. The Air Force reports identified Project Mogul as the source of the 1947 debris and concluded that other alien crash accounts were likely misidentified military programs or accidents. The 1997 Air Force report concluded that the alleged “bodies” reported by later eyewitnesses came from memories of accidents involving military casualties and memories of the recovery of anthropomorphic dummies.

Cultural Impact ðŸ”—

This section explores the impact of the Roswell incident on tourism, commercialization, and popular fiction. Roswell’s tourism industry is based on ufology museums and businesses, as well as alien-themed iconography. A yearly UFO festival has been held since 1995.

The incident has been depicted in numerous films and television shows, including Hangar 18, Independence Day, The X-Files, and Roswell.

Widespread speculation of a cover-up led to United States presidents being questioned about the Roswell incident.

item.title: Alien Hunter (2003 Film)
item.description:
Alien Hunter (2003 Film) ðŸ”—

This entry provides information about the 2003 American-Bulgarian science fiction thriller film Alien Hunter. It includes details about the film’s production, plot, cast, and links to external resources.

Plot ðŸ”—

The plot summary details a series of events triggered by a mysterious signal. In 1947, a radio operator disappears while investigating a signal from Roswell, New Mexico. In the present day, the same signal reappears, originating from the South Pole. Cryptologist Julian Rome (played by James Spader) is recruited to investigate an alien object discovered in Antarctica. The object, emitting the signal, contains a deadly virus and an alien. The virus kills members of the research team and threatens a global pandemic. A nuclear strike is ordered to contain the threat. Julian communicates with the alien before it is killed, discovering the virus’s potential to destroy all life on Earth. Julian and three others are rescued by an alien spacecraft moments before the nuclear strike. The government covers up the incident, claiming a nuclear reactor meltdown. The film concludes with the alien spacecraft carrying the survivors leaving the solar system.

Cast ðŸ”—

This section lists the actors and the characters they portray in the film. Key actors include James Spader as Julian Rome, John Lynch as Dr. Michael Straub, Leslie Stefanson as Nyla Olson, and Carl Lewis as Grisham. Other notable cast members include Roy Dotrice and Keir Dullea.

item.title: Big Sur UFO
item.description:
The Big Sur UFO ðŸ”—

This article details a reported UFO incident that allegedly occurred during a 1964 Air Force mission near Big Sur, California. The Air Force team was stationed on a mountaintop to film Atlas missile tests from Vandenberg Air Force Base.

Air Force deployment to Anderson Peak ðŸ”—

From August to November 1964, the U.S. Air Force deployed personnel to the Los Padres National Forest in California. They used a special telescope borrowed from Boston University to photograph missile launches from Vandenberg Air Force Base. Lt. Robert Jacobs was the commander for the Big Sur location, managed by the 1369th Photo Squadron. The team successfully filmed nine launches, including one of an Atlas missile called “Buzzing Bee,” capturing footage of a re-entry vehicle deploying decoy warheads. This technology was highly classified and designed to protect American nuclear weapons from Soviet interception.

Fringe claims of extra-terrestrials ðŸ”—

In 1982, Robert Jacobs wrote about the incident in the tabloid National Enquirer, claiming he had been part of a cover-up and was now breaking his silence. He described film footage of an unidentified object next to a warhead and a senior official’s reaction. Jacobs claimed he was instructed to never discuss the film. Major Florenz Mansmann reportedly confirmed Jacobs’ account in a 1987 letter. Robert Hastings, a UFO author, further popularized the story in 2007. In 2021, Jacobs participated in a press conference to discuss his interpretation of the incident.

Decoy warheads explanation ðŸ”—

Kingston A. George, the project engineer during the incident, disputed Jacob’s claims of extraterrestrial interference in the Skeptical Inquirer. George stated that he, too, had seen footage he wasn’t cleared to see and was instructed not to speak of it. However, George claims he knew the true purpose of the test: filming the deployment of decoy warheads and chaff to confuse enemy air defenses. He attributed the lights Jacobs reported to the explosive deployment of decoys and chaff, not a UFO energy beam.

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the sources cited in the article, including articles from Military.com, Skeptical Inquirer, National Enquirer, and MUFON UFO Journal.

item.title: The Roswell Incident (1980 book)
item.description:
The Roswell Incident (1980 book) ðŸ”—

This entry details the 1980 book The Roswell Incident by Charles Berlitz and William Moore, which significantly contributed to popularizing the Roswell incident.

Background ðŸ”—

This section provides context for the Roswell incident, focusing on the events of 1947 and the renewed interest in the story in the late 1970s.

Events of 1947 ðŸ”—

This subsection outlines the initial reports of the Roswell incident during the “flying disc craze” of 1947, Kenneth Arnold’s sighting, the Roswell Army Air Field’s initial press release about recovering a crashed disc, and the subsequent retraction stating it was a weather balloon.

Roswell revisited ðŸ”—

This subsection explains how the Roswell story gained traction again in 1978 when retired lieutenant colonel Jesse Marcel claimed in an interview with ufologist Stanton Friedman that the debris he recovered was extraterrestrial.

Authors ðŸ”—

This section provides background information on the authors of the book, Charles Berlitz and William Moore. It mentions Berlitz’s previous success with The Bermuda Triangle and their collaboration on The Philadelphia Experiment: Project Invisibility.

Contents ðŸ”—

This section summarizes the book’s central argument: that an extraterrestrial craft crashed in New Mexico while observing nuclear weapons activity, and the US government engaged in a cover-up. It highlights accounts of debris described as “nothing made on this earth” and mentions witnesses like Bill Brazel, Floyd Proctor, and Walt Whitman Jr. The section also notes the book’s introduction of the idea that the debris shown in photos with Marcel was substituted as part of the cover-up. It also mentions the claim that the military sought to discredit the growing interest in flying saucers. The section also notes that the authors claimed to have interviewed over 90 witnesses, but only a fraction of those accounts appear in the book. The section also notes that the book elevated Marcel’s narrative above that of Cavitt, whose description of the debris contradicted Marcel.

Alien bodies ðŸ”—

This section details the book’s introduction of the story about Barney Barnett and archaeology students encountering wreckage and “alien bodies” on the Plains of San Agustin. It also mentions the conflation of the Roswell incident with the Aztec, New Mexico, UFO incident, a hoaxed flying saucer crash promoted by Frank Scully.

Reception ðŸ”—

This section discusses the reception of the book, noting that critics deemed it “a collection of wild hearsay” and that it “did not make the commercial impact its authors hoped.” It also mentions accusations against Moore regarding the Majestic 12 documents.

Aftermath ðŸ”—

This section mentions Moore’s admission at a 1989 MUFON conference that he had engaged in “disinformation” activities against Paul Bennewitz on behalf of the Air Force Office of Special Investigations.

Modern views ðŸ”—

This section references the 1993 inquiry by the General Accounting Office in response to US congressman Steven Schiff, which led to a 1994 Air Force report concluding that the recovered material was likely debris from Project Mogul, a military surveillance program using high-altitude balloons.

item.title: UFO Coverup? Live
item.description:
UFO Coverup? Live ðŸ”—

UFO Coverup? Live (also known as UFO… The Unsolved Mystery on VHS) was a US television broadcast that aired in syndication on October 14, 1988. It is notable for introducing the Majestic 12 hoax to a wide audience and for being the first public mention of Area 51 as a site associated with aliens.

Synopsis ðŸ”—

The program, hosted by Mike Farrell, imitated a live broadcast format despite being pre-recorded. It featured interviews with various figures involved in UFO research and skepticism. Key topics discussed included the 1952 Washington, D.C., UFO incident, the Mantell UFO incident, and the Tehran UFO incident. The program also touched on notable hoaxers like George Adamski and Billy Meier. Soviet UFOlogists were interviewed about Soviet events, including the Tunguska blast. The show included segments on alien abduction experiences, featuring interviews with Budd Hopkins and psychiatrist Rima E. Laibow. The Roswell incident was discussed with Bill Moore, Stanton Friedman, and Jesse Marcel Jr. Robert Emenegger and Paul Shartle were interviewed about the Holloman UFO incident. Skeptics David Williamson, James Oberg, and Herbert Spiegel provided counterpoints. The program incorporated clips from various science fiction films.

A significant portion of the program focused on the Majestic 12 documents, drawing on the work of Bill Moore and Jaime Shandera. Shadow-clad informants Falcon (Richard Doty) and Condor were interviewed, claiming that the US government had agreements with aliens from Zeta Reticuli, who operated a base in Nevada called Area 51. Falcon claimed the aliens were called EBEs and one of them liked strawberry ice cream.

Reactions ðŸ”—

The program received mixed reactions. Philip J. Imbrogno criticized the show for making the study of UFOs look silly, particularly due to the mention of an alien liking strawberry ice cream. Bill Moore admitted that the program contained disinformation. Stanton Friedman expressed regret for his participation, citing issues with the teleprompter and the untrustworthiness of “Falcon” and “Condor.” Bill Knell argued that the program brought the UFO phenomenon to a wider audience. UFO Coverup? Live influenced Chris Carter’s The X-Files.

See also ðŸ”—

The article lists similar films:

  • Unidentified Flying Objects: The True Story of Flying Saucers, a similar film from 1956
  • UFOs: Past, Present, and Future, a similar film from 1974
